Heading: Raised by
Value: Biological Parents.  William E. And Dorothea Cook Rader

Heading: Parent’s marital status
Value: Mother was widowed in 1966, current status unknown.

Heading: Highest degree
Value: B. A. in Administration of Justice from Wichita State University in 1979

Heading: Grades in school
Value: Unknown, but according to Richard Crusinberry, a classmate of Rader’s, Rader was very bright and did well in school.

Heading: Applied for job as a cop?
Worked in law enforcement?
Value: Working as a Compliance Supervisor for Park City, KS since 1990 at the time of his arrest.  Duties included Animal Control, enforcement of city ordinances, nuisance calls.

Heading: Employment status during series
Value: Employed with ADT during most of the series of crimes.

Heading: Marital status
Value: Married to Paula Rader (nee Dietz) for 34 years

Heading: Number of children
Value: 2; 1 M (Brian) living in Connecticut, 1 F (Kerri) living in Michigan

Heading: Living with
Value: Spouse, Paula, a bookkeeper for a local convenience store in Park City

Heading: Animal torture
Value: Possibly unnecessarily tranquilized dogs as compliance officer

Heading: Been to a psychologist?
Value: Defense is reported to have “copies of expert reports and mental exams”

Heading: Victim type
Value: Mostly young women; one family of 4

Heading: Killer age at start of series
Age of victims
Value: Between age 9 and age 62; mean age 27

Heading: Method of killing
Value: The BTK killer would cut the phone lines, break into the home; wait for the victim; bind victim/victims and torture victims before strangling them; the BTK also used a gun and knife in some cases; in some cases, the BTK would move the victim’s vehicle a few blocks away

Heading: How close did killer live?
Value: Most likely drove to crime; lived about 10-12 miles from crime scenes

Heading: Killing occurred in home of victim?
Killing occurred in home of killer?
Weapon
Value: Killer brought weapon with him for the most part, killer may have used items such as cords from window blinds found at scene; also used a gun and knife in some cases

Heading: Sex with the body?
Value: No, but semen was found on and around victims

Heading: Took totem – personal item
Value: Yes; including jewelry, photos and possible audio recordings of the scene

Heading: Left at scene, no attempt to hide
Moved, no attempt to hide
Value: No; did possibly dispose of two victims on nearby dirt roads or under bridges

Heading: Sentence
Value: Most likely life in prison as capital punishment law not passed in Kansas until 1994; 20 years after Rader’s first murder

Heading: Name and state of prison
Value: Sedgwick County Jail, Wichita, KS - soon to be transferred to El Dorado State Prison

Heading: Date of death
Value: N/A; may have been diagnosed with colon cancer; is declining treatment
